bio:treatment.discussion: Pluchea yucatanensis apparently is native along the Gulf and Caribbean coasts of Mexico and Central America, most commonly on the Yucatan Peninsula and in Belize. In the United States, it is known from collections made from 1896 to 1969 in coastal Alabama and Mississippi; it appears to be naturalized in the flora.

Pluchea yucatanensis is similar in habit and general appearance to P. foetida and P. baccharis and has been identified as both; the rosy tinted phyllaries and florets are more similar to those of P. baccharis. The glabrous, slightly thickened, shiny leaves and glabrous phyllaries are recognition traits for the species.
